NOTES: Burkina Faso and Benin retain a border dispute at this 68 km^2^ triangular area of land near the tripoint border with [Togo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Togo "Togo"). In a 2008 meeting, it was declared that the territory was a neutral zone, neither Burkinabé nor Beninese, making it technically unclaimed. According to the UN Refugee Agency in 2015, there were issues of children being born stateless in the area, however a Beninese civil registration office has taken control of registering births in the area.

The Guinean military occupied this village for 1 month from January to February 2013, before withdrawing in preparation of talks. In December 2016, Guinea soldiers and civilians attacked the village, killing 1 and wounding several others, before returning to their side of the border. According to the Guinean Minister of Defence, the Guinean army had been asked not to send any soldiers to this area and had no involvement in this incident.

Part of the [Kashmir conflict](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashmir_conflict "Kashmir conflict"). Both India and Pakistan claim the former independent princely state of [Jammu and Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(princely_state) "Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)"), leading to the [Indo-Pakistani war of 1947](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1947 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1947"). A UN-mediated ceasefire put a halt to the conflict in January 1949. The UN resolution called for both the countries to demilitarise the region, following which a plebiscite would be held. However, no demilitarisation plan acceptable to both the countries could be agreed. The countries fought two further wars in [1965](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1965") and [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1971"). Following the latter war, the countries reached the [Simla Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement"), agreeing on a [Line of Control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") between their respective regions and committing to a peaceful resolution of the dispute through [bilateral negotiations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India-Pakistan_relations "India-Pakistan relations"). An [armed insurgency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir") broke out in 1989 in the Indian administered part of Kashmir, demanding "independence". Pakistan is [believed to provide arms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan_and_state_sponsored_terrorism "Pakistan and state sponsored terrorism") and training to the militants.

Part of the [Kashmir conflict](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashmir_conflict "Kashmir conflict"). Both India and Pakistan claim the former independent princely state of [Jammu and Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(princely_state) "Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)"), leading to the [Indo-Pakistani war of 1947](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1947 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1947"). A UN-mediated ceasefire put a halt to the conflict in January 1949. The UN resolution called for both the countries to demilitarise the region, following which a plebiscite would be held. However, no demilitarisation plan acceptable to both the countries could be agreed. The countries fought two further wars in [1965](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1965") and [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1971"). Following the latter war, the countries reached the [Simla Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement"), agreeing on a [Line of Control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control") between their respective regions and committing to a peaceful resolution of the dispute through [bilateral negotiations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India-Pakistan_relations "India-Pakistan relations"). An [armed insurgency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir") broke out in 1989 in the Indian administered part of Kashmir, demanding "independence". Pakistan is [believed to provide arms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan_and_state_sponsored_terrorism "Pakistan and state sponsored terrorism") and training to the militants.

This is another border dispute in [Sino-Indian border dispute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute "Sino-Indian border dispute"). In China it is known as [South Tibet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Tibet "South Tibet"). Even though It is a border dispute between India and China, unlike Tawang, it has never gone under direct Chinese control. China wants it to be part of her because there are many links between Arunachal Pradesh's monasteries and Tibet's monasteries. So if Tibet is in China's control then Arunachal Pradesh also has to be in Chinese control is China's point of view.

[Kyrgyzstan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyrgyzstan "Kyrgyzstan"): Barak is a tiny Kyrgyz village in the Fergana Valley region (where Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan meet). In August 1999, the area around Barak was occupied by Uzbekistan. Barak became a *de facto* enclave only 1.5 km from the shifted main border. ([Map](http://mapper.acme.com/?ll=40.66667,72.76667&z=12&t=K&marker0=40.66667%2C72.76667)) In August 2018 Kyrgyz and Uzbek authorities agreed to a land swap that would eliminate the exclave. The exchange process may take up to two years. [Tajikistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tajikistan "Tajikistan"): There are three Tajik exclaves, all of them in the Fergana Valley. One of them, the village of [Sarvan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarvan,_Tajikistan "Sarvan, Tajikistan"), is surrounded by Uzbek territory, whereas the remaining two, the village of [Vorukh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vorukh "Vorukh") and a small settlement near the Kyrgyz railway station of [Kairagach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayragach,_Batken "Kayragach, Batken"), are each surrounded by Kyrgyz territory. [Uzbekistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uzbekistan "Uzbekistan"): There are four Uzbek exclaves, all inside Kyrgyz territory in the Fergana Valley. Two of them are the towns of [Sokh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/So%E2%80%98x_District "So'x District") and [Shakhimardan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shohimardon "Shohimardon") and the other two the tiny territories of [Chon-Qora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Uzbekistan#Enclaves_and_exclaves "Regions of Uzbekistan") and [Jani-Ayil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batken_Region#Enclaves_and_exclaves "Batken Region"). There may be a fifth Uzbek exclave inside of Kyrgyzstan. Most of the border in the area is still not demarcated.

Syrian territory captured by Israel in 1967 (the Six-Day War), and unilaterally annexed by Israel in 1981. In 2008, a plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly voted by 161--1 in favor of a motion on the "occupied Syrian Golan" that reaffirmed support for UN Resolution 497; United Nations, December 5, 2008). During the Syrian civil war period, Syrian Arab Republic had lost direct control of the Eastern Golan areas and retreated from cease-fire line with Israel (in favor of various rebel and Jihadist groups), though did regain the area in 2018.

DESCRIPTION: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea administers North Korea, but Article 1 of the [Constitution of North Korea](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_North_Korea_(1972) "s:Constitution of North Korea (1972)") reads: "The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is an independent socialist State representing the interests of all the Korean people." TERRITORY: South [Sakhalin/Karafuto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sakhalin "Sakhalin"), [Kuril/Chishima, and South Kuril/Chishima Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands") (Northern Territories)
DESCRIPTION: After the end of [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the [Japanese government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Japan "Government of Japan") abandoned its territorial claims to the [Kuril Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands") (except for a few islands in the south) and South Sakhalin in The [Treaty of San Francisco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco "Treaty of San Francisco"). However, since the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") did not sign that treaty, the Japanese government has stated that the ownership of those territories is undecided and they do not recognize the territorial claims of the Soviet Union (current the [Russian Federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia "Russia")). For this reason, these lands are shown as unowned land by any country in white color on most official maps in Japan.

[Limbang District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limbang_District "Limbang District") was part of Brunei until it was forced to cede it to the [Raj of Sarawak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raj_of_Sarawak "Raj of Sarawak") in 1890. Since then Brunei is divided territorially into two. It was claimed by Brunei in 1967 in order to reconnect the country. It forms the main part of the [Brunei--Malaysia border#Disputes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brunei%E2%80%93Malaysia_border#Disputes "Brunei--Malaysia border"). Malaysia claimed to settle the issue in 2009, however this was disputed by Brunei.

The conflict arose in 2003 when the Russian authorities started to build a dam towards the island. Ukraine then established a border garrison on the island for a closer surveillance. The reason for the conflict was the fact that Tuzla island's strategic location gave Ukraine full rights over the main channel in the Strait of Kerch and, thus, the access to the [Sea of Azov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_of_Azov "Sea of Azov"). The conflict was based on the division of the [Black Sea Fleet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Sea_Fleet "Black Sea Fleet") and a lease agreement of the Sevastopol Naval facilities.

In 2014, Russian Federation [annexed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation "Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation") the [Crimean peninsula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crimean_peninsula "Crimean peninsula") in a [disputed referendum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Crimean_status_referendum "2014 Crimean status referendum"). Russian ownership of Crimea is recognized by a minority of countries. The [General Assembly Resolution 68/262](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262 "United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262") by votes 100 "in favor", 11 "against", 58 "abstained" and 24 abstentions noted that Crimea was part of Ukraine. But still [Crimea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea "Republic of Crimea") is practically a de facto state of Russia as most of the control is in Russia's hands.

In 1801, during the [War of the Oranges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_the_Oranges "War of the Oranges"), Spain, with French military support, occupied the territory of Olivenza (in [Portuguese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language") *Olivença*). During the [Vienna Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Vienna_(1815) "Treaty of Vienna (1815)"), the signatory powers (including Spain) agreed with the Portuguese arguments concerning its claim on Olivença but Spain never fulfilled its duty of giving the city of Olivença and its territory back to Portugal.

An agreement was signed (and ratified by Croatia's parliament on 20 November 2009) to pursue binding arbitration to both the land and maritime portions of this continuing dispute.

In 2015 collusion between the Slovenian judge on the arbitration panel and a representative from the Slovenian government was uncovered. The Croatian [Sabor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Croatian_Parliament "Croatian Parliament") voted to withdraw from the arbitration, citing allegations of significant breaches of arbitration rules by Slovenia as the reason.

Despite this the arbitration tribunal continued its work, issuing a ruling in 2017.

TERRITORY: [Tigri Area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tigri_Area "Tigri Area") east of the Upper [Courantyne River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Courantyne_River "Courantyne River")
DESCRIPTION: The Tigri Area (Dutch: Tigri-gebied) is a wooded area that has been disputed since around 1840 by Suriname and Guyana. It involves the area between the Upper Corentyne River (also called New River), the [Coeroeni River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coeroeni_River "Coeroeni River") and the [Kutari River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kutari_River "Kutari River"). This triangular area is in Guyana known as the New River Triangle. In 1969 the conflict ran high on and since then the Tigri Area is controlled by Guyana and claimed by Suriname. In 1971 both governments in [Trinidad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago "Trinidad and Tobago") agreed that they continue talks over the border issue and withdraw their military forces from the disputed Triangle. Guyana has never held upon this agreement.

[Kosovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") is the subject of a territorial dispute between the [Republic of Serbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia "Serbia") and the self-proclaimed [Republic of Kosovo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Kosovo "Republic of Kosovo"). The latter [declared independence on 17 February 2008](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence "2008 Kosovo declaration of independence"), while [Serbia claims it](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serbia%27s_reaction_to_the_2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence "Serbia's reaction to the 2008 Kosovo declaration of independence") as part of its [own sovereign territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Province_of_Kosovo_and_Metohija "Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija"). Its independence is recognized by 97 UN member states.

The border was established between Afghanistan and China in an agreement between the British and the Russians in 1895 as part of [the Great Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Great_Game "The Great Game"), although the Chinese and Afghans did not finally agree on the border until 1963. The [Kingdom of Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Afghanistan "Kingdom of Afghanistan") and the [People's Republic of China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China") demarcated their border in 1963.^[[note 2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_territorial_disputes#cite_note-China2-81)^ However, the settlement is not recognized by the Republic of China.^[[note 2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_territorial_disputes#cite_note-China2-81)^

TERRITORY: [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geography_of_Taiwan "Geography of Taiwan"),\\n[Penghu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penghu "Penghu"),\\n[Kinmen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinmen "Kinmen"),\\n[Matsu Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matsu_Islands "Matsu Islands"),\\n[Pratas Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pratas_Island "Pratas Island") and the Vereker Banks
DESCRIPTION: The government of the People's Republic of China claims the entire island of Taiwan, as well as a number of minor islands, such as [Penghu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penghu "Penghu"), [Kinmen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinmen "Kinmen"), and [Matsu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matsu_Islands "Matsu Islands"), that are controlled by the Republic of China. See also: [Anti-Secession Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Secession_Law "Anti-Secession Law"), [Legal status of Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_status_of_Taiwan "Legal status of Taiwan").

DESCRIPTION: The People's Republic of China claims the water off the Natuna Islands that fall under the [nine-dash line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nine-dash_line "Nine-dash line") claim are traditional Chinese fishing grounds. The Republic of China on Taiwan also claims the area.

The [United Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") keeps the Western Sahara in its [list of Non-Self-Governing Territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_list_of_Non-Self-Governing_Territories "United Nations list of Non-Self-Governing Territories") and considers the sovereignty issue as unresolved pending a final solution. To that end, the UN sent a [mission in the territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Mission_for_the_Referendum_in_Western_Sahara "United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara") to oversee a referendum on self-determination in 1991, but it never happened. Administration was relinquished by Spain in 1976.
